title: How to layer bulbs in pots and containers - expert tips from Sarah Raven
text:
If you want to serve up a zingy spring feast of colour, layering is the way to go

One of my favourite sights in any garden is the huge copper at the centre of the cottage garden at Sissinghurst in spring, surrounded by a quartet of towering yews.

The copper is planted with 50 bulbs of one variety of tulip, the colour of their leaves almost perfectly matching the metal.

It is well worth a visit in April to see this planting classic alone. The tulip is 'Prinses Irene', an exceptional variety, ideal for a container, quite short and yet not stumpy, with elegant, silver-blue-green leaves and flowers the colours of a dying fire.

This is an inspiring example of what you can get from bulbs in a pot...
